awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Improving Incentives and Awareness, to Increase the Security Posture of Critical Infrastructures
awd_abstract_narration:
The protection of cyber-physical critical infrastructures such as the power grid, water distribution networks, and transportation networks against computer attacks is a matter of national security, public safety, and economic stability; however, most of these critical assets are owned and operated by private companies with pressing operational requirements, tight security budgets, and aversion to regulatory oversight.  As a result it is not clear that market incentives alone will create enough momentum to improve the security posture of these systems. This project studies how to incentivize investments and risk management for CPS security. A second related problem is that while current cyber-physical infrastructures are monitored by an operations center, this system does not currently help operators identify if a problem, alarm, or fault was the result of a physical accident or if there is any indication that a cyber-attack caused the problem. This second research focus aims to improve the assessment of the security states of these systems by developing the foundations towards an industrial security operations center to help operators identify the root cause (accident or cyber-attack) of alerts.

There is a large body of work focusing on interdependent security with models of firms participating in protection and insurance markets.  Most of the security models and economic interdependent investment formulations focus solely on information technology infrastructures, and are meant to model cybercriminal activities, where attackers are rational profit-driven agents and defenders experience constant security breaches allowing them to generate risk models based on data. In contrast, computer attacks to critical infrastructure systems represent a completely different set of malicious agents. These agents may not be profit-driven and will attack only sporadically. In addition, interdependent physical infrastructures are managed by federated agents, and cyber-attacks will have physical consequences extending the domain of the single firm attacked. This project leverages and extends the literature of investment in reliability for large-scale critical infrastructures as well as insurance, contracts between firms with interdependent assets, and extreme risk.  The second research focus leverages the interest of the CPS industry in analyzing the data collected by sensor networks. Security Information and Event Managers (SIEM) solutions were designed for enterprise IT, and do not include, aggregate, and correlate the sensor data from the physical world. To mitigate this gap this proposal investigates how to aggregate information for a new system incorporating the data from control centers and those from security operations centers, laying thus the foundation to create an Industrial Security Operations Center (ISOC).

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to address the lack of incentives for investing in the security of critical infrastructures. The project was motivated by the observation that market incentives alone will not create enough momentum to improve the security posture of these systems, and therefore we need to study how to incentivize security investments and new risk management formulations to address the cyber-security of critical infrastructures.

In particular, there is a large body of work focusing on interdependent security with models of firms participating in protection and insurance markets. Most of the security models and economic interdependent investment formulations focus solely on information technology infrastructures, and are meant to model cybercriminal activities, where attackers are rational profit-driven agents and defenders experience constant security breaches allowing them to generate risk models based on data. In contrast, computer attacks to critical infrastructure systems like the power grid or water treatment facilities, represent a completely different set of malicious agents. These agents may not be profit-driven and will attack only sporadically. In addition, interdependent physical infrastructures are managed by federated agents, and cyber-attacks will have physical consequences extending the domain of the single firm attacked, which makes interdependent secuirty more challenging as a firm investing in protection might not save them from consequences of attacks, as the attacks to lower-protected firms will impact them as well. 

This project leverages and extends the literature of investment in reliability for large-scale critical infrastructures as well as insurance, contracts between firms with interdependent assets, and extreme risk.

The first part of the project  focused on modeling a real-world example of how a security services company in Colombia ended up making a deal with guerrilla groups in the country so that they would ramp up attacks in their area of service so they would get "more business". We created an economic model of the problem and then showed how to change the contracts made with the security services company so that they wouldn't have any incentive to promote attacks. 

The second part of this project  focused on modeling the problem of investments as a Markov Decision Problem and finding conditions for how to balance prevention, detection, and cyber-insurance from the point of view of the asset owner trying to decide on which security technology to invest in. 

The final part of this project  focused on the externalities under-investment can produce and the role of governments or central planners to facilitate the cyber-insurance market and to improve the protection of critical infrastructures. In particular, we studied how cyber-insurance was different in power systems compared to cyber-insurance in general IT networks, and proposed specific configuration where it might work. 

Lawmakers have recognized the lack of investment in protecting our critical infrastructures and for several years they created and tried to pass legislation to motivate and regulate the protection of our critical infrastructures.

As the general trend is to avoid legislation whenever alternatives are available, a recent focus from the government and DHS has been to study the potential nurturing of the cyber-insurance market for protecting SCADA systems. Our research efforts address this last attempt focusing on the unique particular problems in SCADA and other critical infrastructure systems, and will hopefully serve as a reference point to future government efforts as a coordinating agent to improve the cyber-security investments of critical infrastrcture asset owners.
